Papageorgiou, A.M. Efstathiou, X.E. Verykios* Institute of Chemical Engineering and High Temperature Chemical Processes, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, GR-26500, Patras, Greece (Received 3 November 1993, revised manuscript received 4 January 1994) Abstract The oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to C-hydrocarbons was studied on a series of lithiumdoped titania catalysts by cofeeding methane (Pc,-1-0.5 bar) and oxygen (Po, -0.07-0.16 bar) at 1 bar total pressure in the temperature range of 750-900. The degree of lithium doping was varied between 0 and 4 wt.-% on Li20 basis. Electrical conductivity measurements confirmed that doping (i.e. incorporation of the Li + cations into the crystal structure of Ti02) did indeed occur. At 900, a C-hydrocarbons selectivity of the order of 70%, at a methane conversion level of 12%, was obtained over the 1 wt.-% Li20-doped Ti02 catalyst. This catalytic performance stayed practically constant within a period of 72 h of continuous reaction. Transient kinetic studies of ethene and ethane reactions with the lattice (in the absence of gaseous oxygen) and adsorbed (in the presence of gaseous oxygen) oxygen species of undoped and Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts showed that adsorbed oxygen species are more reactive towards ethene than ethane, while lattice oxygen is more reactive towards ethane than ethene. These results explain well the CHQ/CH6 product ratio obtained under OCM reaction conditions. It was also found that C2-hydrocarbons selectivity correlates well with surface acidity and basicity characteristics of the Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts. Key words: kinetics; lithium; methane oxidative coupling; titanium oxide; transient oxidation kinetics 1. Introduction The influence of surface promoters and dopants on the catalytic performance of Ti02 and other rare-earth oxides for the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) has gained a significant interest among many investigators [ 1-13 ] . As a result of this process, the electron structure (Fermi energy level) [14], oxidation /reduction potential, acidity /basicity characteristics [10,15,16] and oxygen ion mobility [7,17-19] can be altered in a predictable manner. These parameters are expected to influence catalytic rates of surface reactions, which in turn control activity and selectivity parameters. Lane et al. [ 12] have studied a Li /T102 catalyst with variable Li20 content, in the range 0 to 31.7%, under OCM reaction conditions. However, the conditions employed in the formulation of their catalysts were significantly different than those used in the present investigation, primarily as regards calcination temperature and Li20 content. In particular, in the present catalyst, doping of Ti02 with Li + cations did occur during high-temperature diffusion, as evidenced by electrical conductivity measurements. Although no such information is provided for the catalysts employed by Lane et al. [ 12], doping is not expected to have occurred at the relatively low calcination temperature employed. Furthermore, in most cases, the Li20 concentration is well above the solubility limit. Comparison of the results of the two studies is of interest since they show significant differences in the effects of promotion and doping on catalytic parameters. Recent efforts in this laboratory have concentrated on the oxidative coupling of methane to form CZ-hydrocarbons over Ti02 catalysts doped with various cations of valence lower (Li +, ZnZ+) [9,10,19,20] or higher than that of the parent cation (TaS+, Nbs+ W6+) [20]. In these reports kinetic studies as well as studies on catalyst performance at high levels of methane conversion have been presented. In particular, emphasis has been given in correlating the effects of lattice oxygen mobility, surface acidity /basicity characteristics as well as bulk and surface composition with catalytic properties. From those studies, lithium-doped Ti02 appeared to be a promising catalyst for the reaction under study. In the present study, results on the lithium-doped Ti02 catalyst are reported with an optimum lithium dopant concentration and calcination temperature, a high methane pressure (0.5 bar), a CH4/O2 feed ratio in the range of 3 to 7, and at temperatures between 750 and 900. Transient experiments with CZH4/He, CZH6/He, CZH4/O2 and CA/Oz mixtures have also been conducted in order to obtain information concerning the reactivity of lattice and adsorbed oxygen towards CZ-hydrocarbons, and to relate this with the CZHq/CZH6 product ratio obtained under OCM reaction conditions over the Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts. The stability of the Li +-doped Ti02 catalyst with reaction time is also presented. 2. Experimental 2.1. Preparation and characterization of Li +-doped Ti0Z catalysts Lithium-doped Ti02 catalysts were prepared by high-temperature diffusion. Lithium nitrate was used as precursor of the doping Li + cation in appropriate amounts so as to yield lithium concentrations in the range of 0 to 4 wt.-% (based on Li20/ (Li20+Ti02)). The precursor was mixed with Ti02 of the anatase form (Degussa P-25) in a beaker containing distilled water. The slurry was heated under continuous stirring to evaporate the water, and the residue was dried at 110 overnight. The solid material obtained was crushed and sieved to 48 mesh, placed in a ceramic tube and then fired in air at the temperature of 900, D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 43 unless otherwise indicated. The firing procedure involved placing the ceramic tube in a furnace and heating at a rate of 15/min to the calcination temperature, maintaining at this temperature for 6 h and then allowing to cool slowly to room temperature. The Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts were characterized in terms of total surface area (BET), their electrical conductivity and activation energy of electron conduction, surface acidity and basicity characteristics, bulk lattice oxygen diffusion and surface lattice oxygen exchange with '802 [ 19], bulk composition (X-ray diffraction) as well as surface composition (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, XPS). Details of the experimental procedures have been reported elsewhere [ 10,19] . 2.2. Flow system for catalyst performance and transient studies Catalyst testing was conducted in a conventional flow apparatus. This consisted of a flow measuring and control system, a mixing chamber, a fixed bed reactor and an on-line gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 9A). The flow system consists of three compressed gas cylinders: pure methane, 10% OZ/He or pure oxygen, and helium, which are connected to thermal mass flow meters and control valves (MKS, 274C). The flow-rates of gas streams are thus monitored and controlled. In all experiments the methane pressure was maintained constant at 0.5 bar while the oxygen pressure was varied between 0.07 and 0.17 bar, unless otherwise indicated. Helium was used as diluent. The reactor was a quartz tube, 10 mm I.D., the exit of which was a quartz tube of 2 mm I.D. The catalyst particles, of an average diameter of 0.2 mm were placed near the exit tube. The reactor was encased in a furnace (Heraeus) which was controlled by a programmable temperature controller. The temperature of the catalyst bed was measured by a thermocouple placed in the middle of the bed, encased within a quartz thermowell. Separation of the effluent product stream from the reactor was performed on two packed columns, a Carbosieve (for separation of 02, CO, CH4 and COZ) and a Poropak Q (for separation of CO2, CZH4, CZH6, H20 and higher hydrocarbons). The feed was also analyzed using a loop of a sampling valve of the gas chromatograph. Certified calibration gas mixtures were used to calculate response factors of all components. Transient experiments for studying the reactivity of CZ-hydrocarbons with lattice and adsorbed oxygen species of the catalyst were performed in a flow system which has been described elsewhere [ 10,21 ] . Continuous monitoring of the transient responses obtained from the reactor was performed by an on-line mass spectrometer (VG-Quadrupoles, Sensorlab 200D) equipped with a fast response inlet capillary system. The reactor system used consisted of a 7.0-mm I.D. quartz tube of 2.0 ml nominal volume, narrowed to a 4.0-mm I.D. quartz tube before and after the catalyst bed. Heating was provided by a furnace controlled by a programmable temperature controller (Omega Engineering Inc., CN-2010) , whereas the temperature was measured by a K-type thermocouple encased in a quartz capillary tube. The latter was placed in the middle of the catalyst bed. All gases were used at a flow-rate of 30 cm'/ min (ambient). 3. Results 3.1. Influence of Li+-doping of Ti02 on physicochemical structure The influence of Li +-doping of Ti02, at concentration levels between 0 and 4 wt.-% on oxides basis, on the physicochemical parameters of the resulting material was discussed in O D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 a previous publication [ 10] . In summary, BET surface areas, as obtained by argon adsorption at liquid nitrogen temperature, were found to be in the neighborhood of 0.2 M2/ g, not significantly affected by Li+-doping, within the concentration range investigated. X-ray diffraction measurements revealed the presence of Li2Ti03 phase only on the 4 wt.-% Li20doped Ti02 catalyst. Such a phase was not detected at lower Li20 concentration levels. Lithium oxide and lithium carbonate phases were not detected in any of the 1-4 wt.-% Li20/TiO2 catalysts after doping. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of the 4 wt.-% Li20/TiO2 catalyst detected some segregation of Li + at the surface of the material, as compared to bulk phase concentration. Atomic ratios of Ti/O and Li/Ti of 0.35 and 0.42, respectively, were found, to be compared to 0.47 and 0.22, respectively, for the bulk composition. No indication of the presence of Li20 and/or Li2C03 on the catalyst surface before reaction was found by the XPS measurements. Alterations in the electronic structure of Ti02, which is a n-type semiconductor, upon doping with cations of lower valence (Li + ) were determined by measurements of electrical conductivity and activation energy of electron conduction. The former quantity was found to decrease with increasing Li +-dopant concentration in the Ti02 matrix, while the opposite was observed for the latter quantity. These results are in agreement with theoretical predictions and they demonstrate that doping of Ti02 does indeed occur, following the procedure which was described earlier. Surface acidity and acid strength distribution was determined by the amine titration technique [22] while total surface basicity was estimated by carbon dioxide adsorption/ desorption techniques [ 10] . It was found that surface acidity decreased monotonically with increasing Li +-dopant concentration in the catalyst while surface basicity was found to be enhanced upon doping (1 wt.-% Li20/TiO2) and to decrease at higher levels of doping. 3.2. Catalytic performance of LiM02 system There are only limited reports related to lithium-titania catalysts employed in the methane oxidative coupling reaction to form C2-hydrocarbons [ 12,23 ] . However, lithium has been used as a promoter or dopant of many catalysts for the present reaction system [ 11,24-29] . Lane et al. [ 12] have studied the Li/Ti02 catalyst with variable Li20 content, in the range of 0 to 31.7 wt.-%, over a wide range of experimental conditions. Preparation of their Li/ Ti02 catalysts involved calcination at a temperature of 600 while reaction was carried out at temperatures between 650 and 800. It is not certain, and no evidence has been provided, that under these conditions incorporation of Li' cations into the crystal matrix of Ti02 (doping) did take place. On the other hand, Li/Ti02 catalysts employed in the present study were calcined at temperatures between 900 and 1000 and evidence has been presented, in the form of measurements of electrical conductivity and activation energy of electron conduction [ 10], that Ti02 was indeed doped with Li' cations, following the procedure described in a previous section. This is a significant difference between the Li/ Ti02 catalysts employed by Lane et al. [ 12] and those employed in the present study. This difference is also illustrated in the performance characteristics of the two catalytic systems. In the former case the Li/Ti02 catalysts exhibited optimum performance at a Li20 level of approximately 17 wt.-%, they were active at low temperatures and their stability was low since the space-time yield of CZ-hydrocarbons dropped by a factor of 5 after 47 h of operation. In the latter case, the optimal L120 loading is in the range of 1 to 2 wt.-%, the catalysts are active at high reaction temperatures and their stability is significantly better. In addition, XPS measurements performed on the present 4 wt.-% Li20/TiO2 catalyst indicated that some segregation of lithium from the bulk to the surface had occurred, since a Li/Ti ratio of 0.42 was obtained, to be compared to 0.22 for the bulk composition [ 10]. However, the same catalyst (4 wt.-% Li20/TiO2) used by Lane et al. [ 12] showed a Li/ Ti ratio of 0.71. Thus, it can be stated that the Li/Ti02 catalysts prepared and tested by D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 55 Lane et al. [ 12 ] possess a significantly different physicochemical structure as compared to the Li/Ti02 catalysts prepared and tested in the present study. It could probably be stated that the former catalysts exhibited a Li +-promotional effect rather than a dopant effect, the latter being operative in the present catalysts. Doping of Ti02 with foreign cations implies incorporation of the latter into the crystal matrix of the parent metal oxide, at defect sites and/or substituting Ti" cations. The fact that doping of Ti02 with Li + cations did indeed occur, following the methodology described earlier, has been demonstrated by measured alterations in the electrical conductivity and activation energy of electron conduction [ 10] . In general, doping of a semiconducting metal oxide with a cation of valence lower or higher than that of the parent cation results in alterations in the electronic structure of the material, as reflected in shifts of the Fermi energy level and the work function of the surface. Figs. 1-3 clearly demonstrate that doping Ti02 with Li + cations influences significantly its catalytic performance under OCM reaction conditions. The degree of alteration of activity and selectivity seems to be a function of the dopant concentration in Ti02. Thus, an optimal Li20-dopant concentration of ca. 1 wt.-% is shown in Fig. 1 to maximize catalytic activity. Selectivity towards C2 hydrocarbons is more drastically affected by Li' -doping and an optimal concentration of ca. 2 wt.-% Li20 is shown to exist (Figs. 2a and 2b) for selectivity maximization. A comparison of Figs. 2a and 2b also reveals that the order of selectivity with respect to dopant concentration might be influenced by the CH4/OZ ratio. The optimal concentration for yield maximization is ca. 2 wt.-% Li20, as shown in Fig. 3. These alterations in catalytic performance of Ti02 upon doping with Li + cations may be attributed to either or both of the following factors: (a) changes in bulk and surface electronic properties caused by the doping process, such as electrical conductivity, Fermi energy level, surface work function, and oxygen ion mobility [ 14,17,30,31 ]; (b) changes in surface chemical composition and surface properties (i.e. surface acidity /basicity characteristics) caused by segregation of the doping cation to the surface [ 10,15 ] . 4.1.1. Effect of Li' -dopant on methane activity It has been demonstrated recently [ 19] that a good correlation exists between catalytic activity (initial methane consumption rate) and lattice oxygen mobility, as characterized by the activation energy of lattice oxygen diffusion, of the present Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts. The catalyst with the highest activation energy of lattice oxygen diffusion (1 wt.-% Li20) appears to be the most active (see Fig. 1) . It seems that activation of the methane molecule to form CHI radicals requires a less mobile surface oxygen species, in accordance with what has been proposed earlier [32]. It can be further speculated that the catalyst surface may possess [Li+0-] centers which facilitate the stability of O- species and which may be responsible for methane activation. Such centers have first been observed by Ito et al. [24] over the Li/MgO catalyst. X-ray diffraction measurements performed on the 1 and 4 wt.-% Li20-doped Ti02 catalysts revealed that Li2Ti03 is present in the latter catalyst formulation, whereas no such indication was found for the former catalyst [ 10] . It may be appropriate to state that by increasing the L'Z0 dopant concentration, Li2Ti03 is formed at the expense of [Li+0- ] centers on the catalyst surface which results in decreased ability for methane activation. 56 D. Effect of Li +-dopant on CZ-hydrocarbons selectivity It is well established that doping of a semiconductor (such as Ti02) with cations of valence lower than that of the parent cation (Li + in the present case) reduces the n-type semiconductivity of the parent material or even transforms it into a p-type. It has also been shown [ 15 ] that C2 hydrocarbons selectivity under OCM conditions is favored over a ptype semiconducting catalyst. Thus, the significant enhancement of selectivity of Li +-doped Ti02 could be attributed to this factor. However, the fact that an optimal Li20-dopant concentration exists clearly demonstrates that this is not the only factor responsible for alterations in selectivity in the present catalytic system. Evidence for this is found in the reactivity results of ethene with the catalyst surface to form carbon dioxide in the presence of gaseous oxygen (Table 1). It is shown that the specific reaction rate of ethene with adsorbed oxygen species is largely enhanced when Ti02 is doped with Li + cations. On the other hand, there is a decrease in the combustion rate of ethane to form carbon dioxide when Ti02 is doped with Li' cations. The results of the reaction rate of ethane with the lattice oxygen of the catalysts are also important, pertaining to conditions of high oxygen conversions under OCM reaction. Table 2 shows that when Ti02 is doped with Li' cations, the reaction rate of ethane with lattice oxygen is drastically reduced, while there are only small effects on the combustion rate of ethene (Table 1). As mentioned earlier, doping of a semiconductive metal oxide with altervalent cations influences not only bulk properties but also surface properties, such as acidity and basicity as well as acidic/basic strength distribution. Results on the acidity and basicity characteristics of the present Li20/TiO2 catalysts were reported recently [ 10]. Acidity and acid strength distribution was determined employing the amine titration technique while basicity was determined by selective carbon dioxide chemisorption. The basicity measurements performed were directly related to the basic character of surface oxygen anion species. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of carbon dioxide revealed two well-resolved peaks [ 10] , likely attributed to two different oxygen species; that of lattice oxygen and O-, the latter associated with the [Li+0-] centers as previously discussed. A correlation between selectivity and total surface acidity /basicity is attempted in Fig. 7. It should be stated, however, that surface acidity /basicity was not varied independently but only through the doping process, as a result of which many other catalyst parameters varied, as discussed earlier. Thus, the results of Fig. 7 should be viewed with extreme caution and only very general conclusions should be attempted. It is probably safe to state that surface acidity is detrimental to selectivity, in accordance with results of other investigators [ 33 ] . The weak maximum observed in selectivity at low levels of acidity might also indicate that low surface acidity might improve selectivity, as also mentioned by Becker and Baerns [ 16] . A significant enhancement of selectivity with increasing surface basicity is observed. At high values of basicity, however, selectivity seems to be somewhat reduced. These results are qualitatively similar to those reported over La203-CaO catalysts [ 16] . 4.1.3. Effects of temperature on C,-hydrocarbons selectivity The fact that selectivity to CZ-hydrocarbons formation is, to a large extent, governed by surface processes is illustrated in Fig. 4 in which selectivity is shown to increase with increasing temperature, in the range of 750 to 900, at constant methane conversion. This result implies that the rate of CZ-hydrocarbons formation increases with temperature in a D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 57 larger extent than the rate of CO. formation. This is consistent with the relative values of the activation energies of the two reaction routes. It was found that the activation energy of Cz hydrocarbons formation is approximately 8 kcal/mol higher than that of CO., formation [ 10] . The beneficial influence of temperature on selectivity is maintained even at high temperatures although gas-phase combustion reactions at these temperatures are expected to play an increasingly significant role. If it is assumed that coupling of CH; radicals (formed on the catalyst surface) occurs in the gas phase, as reaction temperature increases the rate of coupling of CH; radicals to form ethane is expected to increase. However, it is also true that the rate of combustion of ethane and ethene to form CO. in the gas phase is also expected to increase with increasing temperature. The variation of selectivity with temperature may further imply that the surface coverage of carbon intermediate species which are in the pathway for CZ hydrocarbons and CO. formation must increase or decrease, respectively, with increasing reaction temperature. The transient results of Figs. 9 and 11 and others reported earlier [21,34] show that the conversion of ethene and ethane to carbon dioxide by lattice oxygen leads to surface carbonaceous species. The amount of these species which react with gas-phase oxygen to produce carbon dioxide decreases with increasing reaction temperature in oxygen flow. This observation is consistent with the results of Fig. 4. In addition, the studies with CZH4/ OZ and CZH6/OZ mixtures revealed that the rate of combustion of ethene to form carbon dioxide decreases to a greater extent with increasing temperature (Table 1) than the increase of the rate of ethane combustion (Table 2). 4.1.4. Effects of methane and oxygen pressures on CZ-hydrocarbons selectivity It was found that increasing the methane pressure from 0.3 to 0.5 bar and the oxygen pressure proportionately so as to keep the CH,/02 ratio constant at 3 or 7, results in an increase in methane conversion for a given WIF ratio. This result is consistent with the positive order of reaction rate with respect to both methane and oxygen [ 10] . However, selectivity decreases with increasing reactants pressure at a given methane conversion level. This result may be attributed to enhanced rates of combustion in the gas phase due to increased oxygen pressure. However, this is not necessarily the only factor since the same phenomenon was observed at low temperatures at which gas-phase reactions are not significant. To explain correctly the effects of oxygen pressure on CZ selectivity, the effects of oxygen pressure on the kind and coverage of adsorbed oxygen species which are in the reaction pathway to form CO,, from methane, and the interaction of ethane and ethene with such species must be understood. The reactivity results of ethene and ethane with the catalyst surface (Tables 1 and 2) indicate that the rate of ethene combustion in the presence of oxygen over the 2 wt.-% U20 M02 catalyst is much larger than the corresponding reaction rate of CZH6/OZ mixture. The opposite behavior is found for the rate of combustion of ethene and ethane with the lattice oxygen of the catalyst (CA/He and CZH6/He feed mixtures). It is suggested that the presence of gaseous oxygen leads to the formation of adsorbed oxygen species, like O-, which decrease, on an average basis, the effective charge of Ti' + and Li + cations on the surface, as compared to that found in the presence of lattice OZ- species and oxygen vacancies. The Ti" and Li + cation species, as well as adsorbed/ lattice oxygen species may be viewed acting as pairs of centers for ethene and ethane chemisorption and hydrogen abstraction with subsequent reactions to form carbon dioxide. 58 D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 It seems that chemisorption of ethene on the aforementioned sites becomes stronger when the effective charge of these sites is reduced. This, in turn, increases the rate of C-C bond breaking, eventually leading to carbon dioxide. The oxygen pressure is, therefore, an important parameter in controlling the coverage of adsorbed oxygen species, and in turn the combustion of ethene and ethane. 4.1.5. Distribution o f reaction products The product distribution obtained over the 1 wt.-% Li20/TiO2 catalyst at 750 and 850 with a CH4/OZ ratio of 3 is illustrated in the form of C2H4/C2H6 (Fig. 5a) and CO/COZ (Fig. 5b) ratios as a function of methane conversion. It is apparent that at both temperatures the C2H4/C2H6 ratio increases with increasing methane conversion. This is probably due to ethane dehydrogenation which is favored at longer reactor space-times which are required to achieve higher methane conversions. The ethane dehydrogenation reaction is also favored at higher temperatures. However, this behavior of the C2H4/C2H6 ratio with increasing methane conversion can also be explained based on the following observations: the increase of methane conversion is of course accompanied by an increase of oxygen conversion as shown in Fig. 5a. At CHQ conversions in the range of 25-30% the oxygen conversion is in the range of 95-99%. The results of Tables 1 and 2 show that the rate of ethene combustion to carbon dioxide by lattice oxygen is much smaller than that obtained in the presence of gaseous oxygen, while the opposite is true for the case of ethane. Thus, under conditions of low oxygen pressure in the reactor (high oxygen conversions) ethane is oxidized more rapidly than ethene giving rise to higher C2H4/C2H6 ratios. However, the fact that at low oxygen concentrations dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene may be favored cannot be ruled out. Fig. 5b indicates that the CO/CO2 ratio decreases with increasing methane conversion at both reaction temperatures, while it increases with temperature. It should also be mentioned that at lower temperatures the selectivity towards carbon monoxide was found to be nearly independent of conversion, while the selectivity towards carbon dioxide was found to increase rapidly with increasing methane conversion. Furthermore, the reaction of ethane and ethene with lattice and adsorbed oxygen over the present catalysts was found to produce almost exclusively carbon dioxide [21,34]. Thus, the variation of the CO/COZ ratio with methane conversion can be attributed to carbon dioxide production by the interaction of ethane and ethene with the catalyst surface. It is also shown in Fig. 5b that the CO/COZ ratio is enhanced at higher temperatures. This observation is probably due to the fact that at 850 gas-phase combustion of ethane and ethene becomes important. It has been shown by Lane and Wolf [ 35 ] that these gas-phase reactions lead primarily to carbon monoxide, which would indeed increase the CO/CO, ratio. Another source of carbon monoxide might be water reforming of ethane and ethene which may become appreciable at higher temperatures. These reactions would also tend to increase the CO/COZ ratio with increasing temperature. 4.2. A comparison of the catalytic performance of Li' -doped Ti02 with other OCM catalysts It is difficult to compare the catalytic performance of the present Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts with that of other catalysts reported in the literature. This is primarily due to the fact that D. Papageorgiou et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 111 (1994) 41-62 59 (a) there are only limited reports on the stability of various catalysts that seem to have "good" catalytic performance under OCM reaction conditions, and (b) CZ-hydrocarbons selectivity vs. methane conversion results are rather limited in the literature. The latter relationship is essential in order to evaluate the catalyst performance correctly. Furthermore, many reports which have appeared in the literature have dealt with dilute feed mixtures of methane (i.e. Pss,4 < 0.1 bar). However, it is recognized that for practical and economic reasons the feed must be significantly more concentrated. It is well established that the general trend is that CZ-hydrocarbons selectivity and yield decrease with increasing methane partial pressure at the same CHQ/OZ ratio. In spite of these difficulties it can be stated that the performance of the present Li +-doped Ti02 catalyst (calcined at temperatures between 900 and 1000) competes well with that of Li /Mg0 [ 11,13,24], doped SM203 materials [ 11 ], various alkaline earth compounds [36], alkali-promoted oxides [29,37], and other catalytic systems reported in recent review papers [38-40]. 4.3. Some mechanistic aspects of the OCM reaction over Li +-doped T1OZ catalyst The transient results of Figs. 8 and 10 clearly demonstrate large differences in the kinetics of combustion of ethene and ethane to carbon dioxide over the lattice oxygen of undoped and Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts. The Li +-dopant has certainly affected the surface chemical properties of titania, which in turn has affected certain elementary steps of the reaction sequence of CZ-hydrocarbons combustion to carbon dioxide. Based on recent transient work reported elsewhere [34], it was suggested that the Li+-dopant affects more one of the oxidation steps of CH,, and/or CHx0 intermediate species, the latter formed after reaction of ethene or ethane with lattice oxygen, rather than one of the steps of the formation of these species (i.e. chemisorption of CZ-hydrocarbons and cleavage of C-C bond). It is shown in Fig. 10 that at 700 for both catalysts the reaction of ethane with lattice oxygen produces three peaks. For the case of Li +-doped Ti02 catalyst, we have extensively discussed the origin of these peaks in a previous publication [ 21 ] . In summary, peak 1 (overshoot at time zero) is consistent with the initially high surface concentration of lattice oxygen species and the formation of a very active CH, and/or CHx0 species. Peak 2 (formed after 4 min on stream) is due to the oxidation of carbonaceous species which have been accumulated in "island" forms during reaction. Diffusion of lattice oxygen from the bulk to the surface gives rise to a critical oxygen coverage, which results in a large rate enhancement of oxidation to carbon dioxide of the aforementioned carbonaceous species. Peak 3 (formed after 7 min on stream) may have the same origin as peak 2, but it may also be due to the oxidation of a less active carbonaceous species formed in a previous reaction time. In the case of undoped Ti02, peak 3 appears as a shoulder in Fig. 10, whereas the appearance of peak 2 occurs at a shorter time-on-stream. Based on a kinetic model presented elsewhere [21 ], the latter behavior is explained as due to the different activation energy of the ratelimiting step for the oxidation of the intermediate species, CH. and/or CH.O. A similar behavior is observed in Fig. 11, where the oxidation (in the presence of gaseous oxygen) at 845 of the carbonaceous intermediate species formed after reaction of ethane with lattice oxygen results in the appearance of the carbon dioxide peak maximum at different times-on-stream in oxygen flow for the undoped and Li +-doped Ti02 catalysts. 60 D.
